Bourbon Barrel Foods' Italian cooking classes

Bourbon Barrel Foods to offer 3 cooking classes with chef Gina Stipo

Bourbon Barrel Foods' Italian cooking classes

Dana McMahan, Special to The Courier-Journal 1:15 p.m. EST November 24, 2014

Gina Stipo(Photo: Provided)

CONNECT 2 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

On Dec. 2, Tuscan-trained chef Gina Stipo will lead the first in a series of three Italian cooking classes Ecco la Cucina "Here's the Kitchen" at Bourbon Barrel Foods, 1201 Story Ave.

The class, held from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. features demonstrations of four traditional Italian holiday dishes. On the menu: fried polenta and mushrooms; hand-rolled spaghetti, pecorino cheese and Bourbon Barrel Foods cured pepper; roasted pork loin, fennel pollen and fresh fennel; and fried chestnut ravioli rolled in Bourbon Barrel Foods sugar.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Bourbon Barrel Foods opening retail store on Frankfort Avenue

"The four courses follow the traditional way Italians eat," explains Stipo, "with antipasto, a first course of pasta and they can come up and have a hand in making that. Pasta in Italy is never put on the side of the meat dish. After that we'll do a meat dish, and then a dessert. I'll demonstrate how the dish is made, and cook it and let them taste it."

Stipo hopes to share the wide variety of foods in Italy with these classes, which continue on Jan. 14 and Feb. 4. "We generalize Italian food. There's really no such thing it's so diverse," she says. "In my classes I try to help people understand and appreciate the diversity of Italian food. It's so much more than meatballs and red sauce."

READ MORE | Shop local for the holidays

Stipo spent 13 years in Siena, Italy, where she ran culinary tours and cooking classes. When she decided to move back home to the United States, she put Louisville on the short list, she says, after visiting and falling in love with the city in 2009. "There are so many things I love about this town." The chef, who received her culinary arts degree from the Institute of Culinary Education in New York City, has plans for other Italian classes and events.

Ecco la Cucina classes cost $55 and include tastings and a cocktail. To make a reservation, call Bourbon Barrel Foods at (502) 333-6103. Learn more: EccolaCucina.com.

Tell Dana! Send your restaurant "dish" to Dana McMahan at thecjdish@gmail.com and follow @danamac on Twitter.
